name: Are your ideas and brands protected? Demystifying Patents and Trade Marks
html_description:
Possessing IP rights (patents, trade marks, copyright) is a source of competitive advantage and a reward for creativity. Protection of those rights is critical for your business and can mean the difference between success and failure. Forresters will provide clear guidance on these topics, using examples of client success stories, and will be available for one-to-one consultations with attendees afterwards.

This event is aimed at business owners, manufacturers, marketing directors and managers, technical directors and managers, product designers, branding consultants, solicitors, law firms, accountants, but it doesn’t have to be limited to that type of business. We will help attendees identify the many aspects of their business that can be protected (for example, their name and logo, designs, inventions, trade marks, creative works) to appreciate the value of those assets and to protect themselves from their competitors.

Attendees will learn about the different types of IP, identify what IP they have themselves (ALL businesses will have some IP) and, will appreciate the importance of protecting these valuable assets. With clear and jargon-free advice, Forresters will explain the steps they need to take to get protection in place.

name: Business Continuity - It's not just about the IT
html_description:
When people think of Business Continuity they usually think of IT – what happens if the power goes off, what happens if the emails go down, what happens if the system gets a virus and whilst we can feel completely lost during those times a business is not just about its IT. Business Continuity plans should incorporate all aspects of the logistics and operations of your business – what if your building gets flooded, the boiler packs up, a key member of staff is on long term sickness or coming up to retirement, what if you stock does not get delivered on time? Small spanners can cause big problems and sometimes you don’t know a spanner is a spanner until its in the works.

Good planning, good foundational documents and insurance can assist in providing business continuity when things go wrong minimising the negative effects on your business. Come along and find out how you can help plan for those unexpected circumstances.

This event is for owners and managers of all types of businesses, especially SMEs where minor events can have a major impact.

By attendin this event, attendees will learn how to carry out a business continuity audit, what measures can be put in place to practically aid business continuity, what steps to take in a “disaster” event, how insurance can underpin your business continuity plan.

name: Effective Governance as Competitive Advantage
html_description:
Considering the challenges faced by SMEs, this mini conference will raise awareness of avenues to building effective governance systems in SMEs as a way to gain competitive advantages.  SMEs in the Black Country are challenged by fierce global competition. Developing new technologies, investments, access to skilled labour etc. have been paths that made British industry flourish historically. However, these are all challenging tasks today and we need new ways of effective and informed governance systems to manage this challenging era of SMEs.

The session will deliver state of the art research and insights from knowledgeable practitioner to the delegates. Effective governance is thus the focus for the seminar and will be delineated by scholarly definitions as well as practitioners’ insights.

The conference will benefit the local SME community by raising the awareness of avenues to building effective governance systems in SMEs as a way to gain competitive advantages. While the delegates will be informed of the current practices in British SMEs, we will also discuss future avenues and challenges for SMEs in this regard. By joining IoD the conference combines a practitioner view with state of the art research on corporate governance which furnishes delegates with better understanding of roles and structure of governance systems and practical tips about how to achieve effective governance in their firms.

This mini conference is arranged in partnership with IoD West Midlands and Project GoSMEs at the Business School, University of Wolverhampton. The conference includes sessions with presentation of overall result from a recent survey about the governance of SMEs in the UK, Sweden and Denmark. This has been enabled through project GoSMEs, a research project funded by the European Union’s Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation programme under the Marie Skłodowska-Curie grant agreement No 748905, at the University of Wolverhampton.

Session outline:

• Sharing a recent survey on governance of small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) in the UK and Europe.

• The challenges of SMEs regarding effective governance.

• Panel discussion with practitioner and academics on governance in SMEs as competitive advantages.

Speakers:

Silke Machold, Dean of Research and Professor of Corporate Governance at the University of Wolverhampton

Daniel Yar Hamidi, Research Fellow at the University of Wolverhampton and a representative from the IoD

html_description:

Agile is one of the fastest growing product development techniques in the world. It originated in the software industry but is now being used in all kinds of businesses.

One of the key roles in Agile and the Scrum framework is that of the Scrum Master. This was one of the top 10 jobs in 2018 according to linked in and demand is still increasing.

This course will give an introduction to the agile product development framework and key roles such as the Scrum Master.  This will be achieved by participative team based activities that let you experience first-hand how Scrum works.

If you are a team in charge of delivering a product or project, an individual preparing to work with or on an agile team, a Project Manager entering the Agile environment, or someone who just wants to learn what all the fuss is about with Agile and Scrum, this taster is perfect for you.

• Introduction to Agile and Scrum

• When do we use Scrum?

• The Scrum Framework through group activities.

name: What makes a good Charity Trustee?
html_description:
The seminar will explore the role and responsibilities of charity trustees, with different perspectives being offered by three speakers as follows:

Kirsty McEwen, Partner in the Charity and Not for Profit team at Higgs & Sons will explore what makes a good trustee from a legal perspective, to include an explanation on the restrictions of who can be a charity trustee; how to find good trustees, recruit, induct, retain and train them; and the legal framework within which charity trustees operate. The session will focus on the ever increasing regulatory burden placed on charity trustees and how best to recruit people to ensure diversity on the board and enshrine good governance.

James McLaughlin Chief Executive of Cure Leukaemia will explore what makes a good charity trustee from the perspective of the senior management team. He will provide some unique insights, as a chief executive, into what senior management require from the board and what he considers to be the key skills, motivations and drivers that charity trustees should bring to the table.

Clive Bawden will provide his unique insight into his experience of acting as a charity trustee as compared with being a non executive director of a commercial organisation. He will look at what being a charity trustee means to him, and what he gains both professionally and personally.  

The event is aimed at existing charity trustees, those who might be considering the role of a charity trustee and those involved in recruiting charity trustees at either Board level, senior management or otherwise.

Higgs & Sons Charity and Not for Profit Team, together with the Institute of Directors, will be co-hosting the event which will be focused on the particular considerations that need to be considered when recruiting and retaining charity trustees. 

The Attendees will gain an understanding of what it means to be a charity trustee from a legal and regulatory point of view; what boards of trustees might be looking at in terms of recruiting trustees; what senior management consider to be useful skills for charity trustees to bring to bear; and what they can personally gain from this unique role.  

The event will be held at Higgs & Sons' Waterfront headquarters, with welcome teas and coffees in the atrium.  The seminar will be hosted in our dedicated meeting rooms.

Kirsty will also focus on the regulatory framework that surrounds the role, issues and concerns such as risk and liability of being a charity trustee, as well as the key duties and responsibilities. Kirsty will explore how best to find new trustees, recruit, induct and keep them, as well as diversity on trustee boards.

10.45am: James McLaughlin, CEO of Cure Leukaemia will consider the role and responsibilities of charity trustees from the point of view of the senior management team and what makes a good trustee from the perspective of those who sit on the executive.

Speakers:

Beverley Nielsen – Associate Professor

West Midlands born, Beverley Nielsen, is passionate about the region, believing we sit in the heartland of UK makers and creators, with a goldmine of young talent.

She is Associate Professor and Director at IDEA Institute, the Institute for Design & Economic Acceleration at Birmingham City University, where she has worked for the past 10 years as Visiting Tutor, MA Design Management, Director Employer Engagement and Director Corporate Affairs. Beverley has launched a number of initiatives whilst at the university including 'Birmingham Made Me', with a focus on promoting the Midlands' manufacturing excellence along with design and brand-led businesses. 

She has helped start up over 40 new companies involved in diverse areas including fashion, jewellery, interiors, integrated healthcare, outdoor activities, connected & autonomous vehicles, bicycle accessories and ultra-light rail.

Previously Director of FTSE 250 business AGA Rangemaster plc and MD of subsidiary business, Fired Earth, she was also Director of CBI West Midlands having spent 10 years working for the CBI as a European policy advisor and Assistant Director, CBI North West. 

She has been recognised for her contribution to business in the region as Midlands Business Woman of the Year, the Business Desk's West Midlands Ambassador of the Year, the ALL Ladies League Woman of the Decade in Enterprise and Leadership and was awarded an honorary master’s degree from Coventry University. 

Beverley is proud to have been an Associate Fellow at WMG, the University of Warwick for the past 18 years and is a Director of ART Business Loans.

She was elected a Councillor in Worcestershire in 2009, before standing as the first and only female candidate in the first election for the West Midlands Metro Mayor.

Lisa Cowley - CEO Beacon Institute for the Blind

Educated at Wolverhampton Girls High School Lisa has worked for a number of charities throughout her career after gaining a First-Class Honours degree in Zoology and Evolutionary Psychology from Liverpool, University.

Before joining the Beacon Centre, Lisa was Deputy Chief Executive at the Black Country Living Museum and was instrumental in securing £9.8 million form HLF and £8 million from Black Country LEP funding.
Working on management and development of the museums’ enterprise activities including Food & Drink and Retail, she helped deliver c £1.7 million turnover for the site.

Her career has seen her in campaign roles with the British Horse Society, Friends of Flaxmill Maltings in Shropshire and the Conservation Volunteers organisation.

Lisa’s current role at The Beacon Centre encompasses overseeing the development and delivery of all Beacon’s care and support services, stimulating new ideas and innovation as well as creating new partnerships and collaborations which help Beacon provide better services. Through Lisa’s strategic vision, Beacon aims to truly make a visible difference to those living with sight loss.

She said, “I have always worked within the Charity sector, which has been a conscious decision of mine as I’m really passionate about making a difference. I feel very lucky to be part of the team at Beacon, who are all so driven to support others, improve people’s prospects and change perceptions. Working together, I am confident we will help create a society where individuals value and protect their sight and a visual impairment does not limit or determine opportunities”.

Professor Michelle Shaw - Director of Educations & CEO University of Wolverhampton Multi Academy Trust

A Professor in Education with over 25 years’ experience working in Schools, FE and HE with extensive experience of senior leadership and management, Michelle will give an insight into current women in leadership research data, the challenges this throws up, her own lived experiences as a senior leader in Education and the ways in which,  through school education, we can begin to make a difference?

Teresa Boughey MA Chartered FCIPD Founder and CEO of National Award-Winning Jungle HR a strategic HR Consultancy Practice that works with Executive Boards and Leadership Teams during times of change and business transformation. 

Described by her peers as personable, innovative and high energy.  Teresa has operated at Senior level within a variety of industries and sectors including FTSE 250, Financial Services, Travel Industry, Private and Public Sectors, Charitable Organisations and a Sunday Times Top 100 Company that grew 30% year on year. 

Her achievements are award winning and include leading on the acquisition of the iconic Gleneagles hotel, delivering business transformation programmes across Europe achieving combined cost savings of c3.5million euros as well as providing Executive Coaching to Board & C-suite members.

Teresa has also been appointed to one of only 50 UK Female Entrepreneur Ambassador roles and is currently a member of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Women and Enterprise and also the Women and Work All Party Parliamentary Group. 

Her book, ‘Closing the Gap – 5 steps to creating an Inclusive Culture’ provides Corporate CEOs and HR Directors with a clear framework which can be used to create a culture that welcomes diversity and aims to close the gap in gender pay using her TRIBE methodology.

As an active fundraiser Teresa has also helps raise funds for various charities and is currently an Ambassador for The Hunger Project – Unleased Women’s Project.  

Teresa will speak about Closing the Gap and how to weave diversity throughout organisations.

name: Diversity – is it just a tick box exercise?
html_description:
How to increase diversity in your workforce, what are the benefit and challenges. Join us in the debate along with business leaders and professionals - how they overcame the barriers and what works.

This will be an informative and valuable event for MDs, Directors, HR and Diversity professionals who are looking at becoming more inclusive.  Attendees will gain information, ideas, open debate, opportunity to discuss what they are doing or want to do. 

There will be a Keynote speaker, guests and a panel to lead the debate and answer your questions.  

Promoting diversity and inclusion in the workplace is one of hottest topics for 2019. People professionals understand that it’s about valuing everyone in the organisation as an individual.

However, to reap the benefits of a diverse workforce it’s essential to have an inclusive environment where everyone feels able to participate and achieve their potential.

Whilst legislation in the UK protects job applicants and workers from discrimination, an effective diversity and inclusion strategy goes well beyond legal compliance – through helping organisations to build a collaborative, supportive environment that increases the participation and contribution of all employees. 

In a nutshell, it’s about empowering people by respecting, appreciating and harnessing what makes them different!

Creating a common understanding of diversity and inclusion – practical steps, easy wins and what to avoid.

Ways to build and develop diverse teams and supply chains that achieve success. Do’s and don’ts.

Lunch will be provided at the start of the event.

name: Re-Integrating Young Offenders - Careers Speed Networking Event

So, are you a business in the Black Country? Would you like to get involved in a ‘Job Opportunities Speed Networking Event'? Could you offer a morning of your time on 20th May to talk to young people aged 18-25 to provide guidance and advice about your company, sector and the possible route to a job or further education? If so register your interest now.

HMP/YOI Brinsford, together with: Beating Time (a charity who run weekly team building groups in prisons, improving mental health, social inclusion and developing employability skills of participants), Rubery Owen and the University of Wolverhampton, invite you to register your Business to be involved in an exciting opportunity to meet some of tomorrow's workforce.

Be part of a job opportunities networking event to: help young people of the Black Country take steps towards getting their life back on track; improve your understanding of the potential of the people in our prisons today; find out the breadth of skills and experience of the young gentlemen in Brinsford; and be able to discuss with them what your business or education services may have to offer them!

This event will take place as part of the Black Country Business Festival and is looking for businesses to become involved with the aim to increase employer/prison interaction, increase awareness of the potential of the prisoners in our region and enlighten young people to the array of job opportunities available to them.

The format of the event will see attendees given the chance to speed network with local and national businesses. Around 30 young prisoners will attend allowing employers to showcase the profile of Black Country businesses.

1) The morning will start with a networking session aimed at the business volunteers. It will include a talk from Steps to Work, about the benefits to organisations that employing ex- offenders can bring as well as the practical advice and support that they provide to employers.

2) The speed networking will then follow on and will host over 200 individual speed network conversations.

3) This will then be followed by a buffet lunch and a talk from the prison Governor.

The event is aimed at individuals from local businesses or higher education establishments who are interested in finding out the potential of the young gentlemen in Brinsford prison who are willing to explore giving ex-offenders jobs or further education opportunities.

You will gain a better understanding of the potential within our prison system. There are 85,000 people in our prisons today and a high % of them have something really positive to offer to employers.

html_description:
There are 10 common mistakes employers make when it comes to their employees.  Avoiding these can make your life as an employer much happier.  Getting the small things right as an employer can save you lots of time and money and avoid big things going wrong.  Whether it's getting your contracts in order, calculating holiday properly, dealing with probationary periods or handling sickness absences, objectively dotting the i's and crossing the t's does not necessarily mean more paperwork and red tape.  You can avoid lots of paperwork later and possibly even legal costs and tribunal awards and it can make you an attractive employer to work for.

The event is aimed at HR Managers, Managers responsible for employing or supervising staff and business owners without a dedicated HR resource.

You will gain knowledge about common mistakes made when it comes to employees from hiring to firing and how to avoid them and the wider consequences they can cause.  For example, not dealing properly with probationary periods can cause difficulties later on when an employer wants to dismiss for poor performance.

The highly interactive workshop is appropriate for delegates who are new or relatively inexperienced exporters, or  current exporters who are looking to improve their marketing and sales strategies.

We encourage attendees to reflect on the issues covered as they affect their own businesses and also group delegates together to give them every opportunity to share their experiences and relevant case examples with others who may have similar products and/or services or target customers.

All delegates receive a set of notes and exercises to help them plan and prepare for sales and marketing activities with potential customers overseas.  These can be used to help throughout the process and for targets in any sector in any export market.

If I had a £ for every time I was told:

“We downloaded our terms from the internet” or “We have used a customer’s terms” 

The recent debacle with the government shipping contract where the provider’s terms included provision for pizza delivery is a prime example of how dangerous this can be.

If I had a £ for every time I was told:

“We don’t have any terms” or “The last time we looked at our terms was 20 years ago” 

If I had a £ for every time I was told:

“We put our terms on the invoice”

I would be a very rich woman.

There are two important steps with your terms and conditions – 1. Making sure they are incorporated in to the contract in the first place and 2. Making sure they suit your business. Coming along to this presentation will give you the areas to think about so you can evaluate whether you need to make changes to your sales processes and whether your terms (if you have them) really provide you with the protection you need and whether with recent changes in the law you are being compliant with your legal obligations especially when it comes to selling to consumers.

Business immigration issues often give rise to employment law issues and vice versa and it is important to ensure that a business is protected on both fronts.

We therefore want to help businesses not only meet those challenges but be better equipped to take advantage of the opportunities it offers so that they can continue to go on making the Black Country one of the most vibrant business communities in the UK.
